text: hey everyone while it may only take four
simple pantry ingredients to make
homemade pasta can even intimidate the
most experienced cooks but today I'm
going to show you a clever new method of
making pasta and we're going to leave
the old-school version of making pasta
behind the old-school method is the well
method where you build the flour up and
then you add the wet ingredients into
the center and you use a fork to kind of
mix it all together inevitably the well
breaks the eggs kind of scatter and it's
kind of a mess and a pain in the butt to
do but the food processor method which
I'm going to show you today is really
simple to do I have two cups of flour
here and I'm using a type of flour
called double zero flour that is a
finely ground Italian flour and if you
find this in a specialty store look and
see on the label if it says pasta flour
because that's what you want and that
protein range is a little higher around
ten to twelve percent which is really
great for pasta now if you can't find
this flour you can certainly use
all-purpose flour it's just going to be
a little chewier your pasta dough so be
aware of that but you can certainly
substitute it so two cups of flour a
hefty pinch of fine sea salt here so
that there's no granular texture within
your pasta dough and now three eggs I'm
going to crack my eggs on a flat surface
not on the side of the bowl if you crack
them on the side of the bowl the shell
kind of goes up into the egg and you
have to fish it out so three whole eggs
right into the food processor here and a
scant tablespoon of extra virgin olive
oil this pasta dough recipe uses whole
eggs there are lots of different
versions and variations of pasta dough
some really rich and tender pasta
dough's use only egg yolks but use a lot
of them this is a great all-purpose
pasta dough that's sturdy but also
wonderfully tender as
so you really want to process this up
until it forms a semi cohesive ball if
it's a little tacky make sure that you
spread enough bench flour onto your
surface so that doesn't stick to your
surface and if it's too dry you can
always add a teeny bit more olive oil
until it does become a cohesive dough
that was so easy it came together in
like 30 seconds now the food processor
really starts the process of kneading
that hard work the blade is doing starts
developing the gluten in the pasta dough
which gives you the texture that you're
looking for but when I talk about
kneading and doing it by hand what it is
is basically pulling over the far side
of the dough with your palm and then
pushing it together and away from you so
I'm going to do this for about three to
five minutes so the dough is no longer
tacky its elastic and I'm just going to
form it into a ball and you move the
dough to a surface that's not slippery
sticky or coated in flour you should be
able to roll the dough pushing down on
the dough with the palms of your hand
while rotating your hands and you should
end up with a nice round ball just like
that wrap this in some plastic wrap this
sits out at room temperature for about
an hour or you could rest it in your
refrigerator up to overnight we have our
dough here and it needs to rest about an
hour I have another one they've already
made it and you can see as it sits it
really starts to soften so I'm going to
take about a quarter of the dough here
to start with and keep the other pieces
well wrapped because pasta dough will
really dry out if you are using a method
where your refrigerating your dough
overnight and using it the next day
bring it to room temperature before you
do this you could roll this out by hand
with a rolling pin there are other
devices out there in the marketplace
where you can attach it to your work
surface and can crank it yourself
I love the attachments that that on the
stand mixers here it really makes easy
work out of this job here so I'm
flattening my pasta dough just like this
have the setting at the widest which is
technically the lowest number
this is on setting number one turn your
speed to very low and I'm flattening out
the dough so that it will fit easily
through the thickest setting on the
attachment so once you pass the dough
through the first time what you should
do and this is a little trick here to
get your pasta to turn out in Nice long
rectangular sheets if you're using this
for lasagna or something like that fold
it into thirds so the tapered ends come
into the center so you're creating more
of a rectangular shape here and now you
can pass your pasta dough through your
attachment and it will keep somewhat of
a rectangular shape so I recommend that
you pass the dough through the same
setting twice before reducing the
setting down to a thinner setting I'm on
the second-to-last setting here and I
think that this is a good size for any
of the pastas like spaghetti or linguine
or fettuccine now if you were doing a
double layer pasta and that's like a
ravioli you want to go to the thinnest
setting on your attachment here so that
the pasta isn't too toothy when you
serve it to your guests so if your pasta
gets a little too long like it is right
now you can certainly cut it in half and
pass it through the machine in a smaller
sheet but this looks good to me and I'm
going to make fettuccine today and you
can fold your pasta up a little bit here
make sure that you use a little bit of
flour so that doesn't stick together
because as the pasta dough sits it will
start to stick and now cut your pasta
don't apply too much pressure because
you don't want it to stick together on
you and gently fluff it up in no time
you have fresh homemade pasta that you
can serve any night of the week if you
have any kitchen conundrums that you
need solved write in the comment section
below or reach out to me using the
hashtag kitchen conundrums and I will
solve whatever kitchen problems you may

you
